Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: With Ann Mellick. Pit is an example of an emerging and evolving persistent weak layer. Some northeast aspects at all elevations are shallow. Where HS is around 120cm the lower half is 2mm facets mid pack and 3mm depth hoar. This location has a small, isolated slab on top. The slab is made up of multiple snow and wind events, now settled into the top 40cm. ECTP 21 @ 45 and CT 11 SC at 45 suggest that where this structure exists, stabilty is poor. So far this is still isolated as many of these shallow areas just dont have much of a slab on top. If you find one you could pop out a little pocket now but more concerning will be once we get the next couple storms adding more load and slab.
ALP, stenig mark

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Our aim for this profile was to explore the snowpack development since the beginning of the season in higher elevations on flat ground. Several layers of concern have been observed, including the graupel layer found so far in all previous snow profiles from the area.
Highly concerning is a thick layer in the middle snowpack of very large facets (depth hoar) that is isolated between two thin crusts.
Right after we filled in our pit and were getting ready to go, the ground collapsed under our feet presumably on that weak layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Currently very stable due to multiple melt/freeze cycles. Chose pit location because pole probing sunk to the ground once through the surface crusts. Currently no avalanche hazard here but if the heat turns on soon and this structure goes isothermal, wet avalanches will be likely.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
End of storm; strong winds from W - NW previous night. The goal of this pit was to compare the results of the previous tests at a shallower snowpack area near avalanche starting zone (big cliff). Following observations were made: the basal laminated melt-freeze crusts have transformed into a large depth hoar layer which collapsed during CT test. The February 4th graupel layer is there and also reactive. In the upper snowpack the recent weather events including short, but heavy snowfall and strong winds from W / NW in the past 24 hours have formed several layers of large precipitation particles mixed with wind broken small grains.
During the time the pit was made, an avalanche accident with 2 skiers involved (1 completely burried) happened on a similar aspect but at lower elevation (Echmishte).

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: light blowing snow, only because so little snow available for transport on windward slopes

Small sheltered slope at TL with HS ranging to 5+m. Surface SH 5-8mm prominent especially in shaded protected areas, rimed at ridgetop. Snow surface becoming moist throughout the day on steep solars below ~1200m.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug adjacent to HS-N-R2,D2.5-O that occurred 4 days prior on Feb 24. Initial slide was a new snow wind slab that stepped down into weak faceted snow mid-pack and at the ground. SE-E aspects still have persistent weak layers that if given the right load will fail. This structure is becoming much more isolated however as the warm temps and stronger sun help with sintering. CT failures suggest once the strength of the slab is reduced failures are still possible.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profile site just below treeline ridge crest, ridgeline scoured from recent S-X W'erly winds. Few storm interfaces in top 40cm, below test depth P to P+ mid pack bridges early season PWLs.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The initial goal was to test the Feb 4th graupel layer, but our attention was quickly drawn to a more recent snowpack problem: a high density wind slab formed during the gale force winds on Feb 24th and especially both interfaces of the slab: graupel on top and a thin layer of facets at the bottom. Although the layer looks quite hard, the facetted layer below is reactive to both CT and ECT.
NWAS Skeena Sawmills - Bish Hans Mundhenk, Eddy Plant

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in wind protected below treeline terrain specifically for a loaded PST on the surface facet layer. Using a 10 cm thick artificial slab constructed on the snow surface using disaggregated snow and allowed to sinter for 1.25 hrs, the tese scored Loaded PST 29/100 SF @ 133cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in below treeline terrain to look at upper snowpack faceting that exists at and below treeline on N aspects. Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Hur tjock är drevsnöflaket? Hur reaktiv?
Open BTL roll Skiers left of South Ymir path Observers: GF, DM

No concerns below the very hard Feb 7th ice crust. Much of the snow above is not necessarily faceted but it remains weak. The warm sunny days and clear cold nights have kept the new snow from bonding to itself. No stability concerns now until a slab forms on top. Perhaps a few wind slabs could be resting on this weak snow and would be unstable.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown of a slide triggered from below, which buried three people while skinning uphill on 2/16/2020. Self rescued and no injuries reported. PST results altered as we found a frozen rollerball in the suncrust, which created a non planar surface. With Joe Dellaporta.
Observers: GB GF Fracture line profile in B7 A/B fan Skier accidental from 200216 Crowns were 25-45cms and failure plane was Feb 13th SH 3-6mm

Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Natural small soft slabs - 2 on SW steep slopes; 1 on NE steep slope under rocks; Later in the day natural thin soft slabs (15-20 cm) on E exposures at about 2000 m a.s.l. От предишния ден и вечерта няколко плитки меки дъски - 2 на ЮЗ и една на СИ под скали; По-късно през деня изтичания по източния склон на Калбура (под Куклата). Северни изложения С пръхкав сняг; Карано на различни изложения без проблеми; Източните склонове следобед напечени, по-късно с лека кора, която се очаква да се топи и замръзва в следващи дни;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: powder snow 10-15 cm with small wind-loading on places, two natural avalanches (small slabs) observed on SW exposures; Тест в дъното на Втора тераса, под големите скали; Нов сняг (10-15 см) с лесно плъзгане, на места навят, 2 естествени плитки (10-20 см) дъски на ЮЗ изложения; В дълбочина под солидна дъска има слой суграшица, различно изразен в долината; За момента стои стабилно, може да е притеснителен при много силни затопляния;
